articles.headline: Medicaid Growth Could Aggravate Doctor Shortage
articles.snippet: Under the new health care law, a wave of additional Americans will soon be covered by Medicaid, a program that has struggled with a shortage of doctors willing to accept its low reimbursement rates and red tape.
articles.abstract: Under the new health care law, a wave of additional Americans will soon be covered by Medicaid, a program that has struggled with a shortage of doctors willing to accept its low reimbursement rates and red tape.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — Dr. Ted Mazer is one of the few ear, nose and throat specialists in this region who treat low-income people on Medicaid, so many of his patients travel long distances to see him.

articles.headline: A Growth Spurt for Middle Eastern Carriers, Led by Emirates
articles.snippet: Emirates, based in Dubai, is building routes to developing countries, providing an alternative to local carriers and buying a lot of big jets.
articles.abstract: Emirates, based in Dubai, is building routes to developing countries, providing an alternative to local carriers and buying a lot of big jets.
articles.lead_paragraph: There is little doubting the ambitions of the giant Middle Eastern airlines, but recent large plane orders demonstrated just how aggressively these carriers plan to compete in coming years.

articles.headline: Mortgages Without Risk, at Least for the Banks
articles.snippet: A part of the Dodd-Frank financial overhaul law is being challenged by a coalition that wants to drop risk retention for mortgage loans.
articles.abstract: A part of the Dodd-Frank financial overhaul law is being challenged by a coalition that wants to drop risk retention for mortgage loans.
articles.lead_paragraph: There was no single cause of the financial crisis, but a chief one was surely the way mortgage loans were made by people who believed they had no reason to care if the loan was repaid.

articles.headline: Shop First, and Eat Later
articles.snippet: Many retailers didn’t wait for the predawn hours of Black Friday this year. They were open before breakfast on Thanksgiving Day, and customers were waiting.
articles.abstract: Many retailers didn’t wait for the predawn hours of Black Friday this year. They were open before breakfast on Thanksgiving Day, and customers were waiting.
articles.lead_paragraph: Before most Thanksgiving turkeys even approached the oven on Thursday, a small line of tents had formed in front of a Best Buy in Falls Church, Va., their inhabitants waiting for the holiday deals to begin. First in line was William Ignacio, who pitched his tent at 2 p.m. on Wednesday.

articles.headline: On Register’s Other Side, Little to Spend
articles.snippet: The struggle of low-income workers, many in retailing, is adding momentum to efforts to increase the federal minimum wage.
articles.abstract: The struggle of low-income workers, many in retailing, is adding momentum to efforts to increase the federal minimum wage.
articles.lead_paragraph: In many stores around the country, the workers stocking the shelves and ringing up the gifts are at the very heart of this season’s retail lament —many Americans are so financially strapped that projections for holiday sales have grown bleaker by the week.

articles.headline: Law Limiting Plastic Guns Set to Expire
articles.snippet: As 3-D printing technology makes it possible to produce weapons that can avoid detection, the police and members of Congress fear the consequences if the Undetectable Firearms Act is not renewed.
articles.abstract: As 3-D printing technology makes it possible to produce weapons that can avoid detection, the police and members of Congress fear the consequences if the Undetectable Firearms Act is not renewed.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the movie “In the Line of Fire,” a deranged killer smuggles a homemade gun past the Secret Service and tries, unsuccessfully, to shoot the president.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: Some Big Public Pension Funds Are Behaving Like Activist Investors
articles.snippet: Some of the biggest public pension funds are engaging with, and sometimes seeking to oust, directors of companies whose stock they own.
articles.abstract: Some of the biggest public pension funds are engaging with, and sometimes seeking to oust, directors of companies whose stock they own.
articles.lead_paragraph: Activist investors like Carl C. Icahn, Daniel S. Loeb and William A. Ackman are getting deep-pocketed imitators.

articles.headline: Despite Outlaw Image, Hells Angels Sue Often
articles.snippet: Just in the past seven years, the Hells Angels have brought more than a dozen cases in federal court, alleging infringement for borrowing the motorcycle club’s name and insignias.
articles.abstract: Just in the past seven years, the Hells Angels have brought more than a dozen cases in federal court, alleging infringement for borrowing the motorcycle club’s name and insignias.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Fritz Clapp, a 67-year-old lawyer with a bright red mohawk, practices intellectual property law. Years ago, his clients were “small-time businesses that nobody had ever heard of.” Then he found something bigger. Today, Mr. Clapp, an eloquent and irreverent man known to wear a purple fez during negotiations with other lawyers, represents the interests of a group not commonly associated with intellectual property: the Hells Angels Motorcycle Club. His main role is not as a bulldog criminal defense counsel for the notorious group but as a civilized advocate in its relentless battle to protect its many registered trademarks.

articles.headline: Retailers’ Sly Message: Get Yourself a Gift, Too
articles.snippet: Self-gifters, who take advantage of frenzied holiday sales to buy a few things for themselves, have been growing in numbers and dollars spent.
articles.abstract: Self-gifters, who take advantage of frenzied holiday sales to buy a few things for themselves, have been growing in numbers and dollars spent.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even the most clueless and bumbling gift-giver probably knows that it is not a good idea to give wrinkle cream, an electric toothbrush or a vacuum cleaner to anyone for Christmas or Hanukkah.

articles.headline: Mixed Legacy for Departing Pakistani Army Chief
articles.snippet: As the taciturn Gen. Ashfaq Parvez Kayani steps down, little has changed in the American-Pakistani relationship despite years of diplomatic effort.
articles.abstract: As the taciturn Gen. Ashfaq Parvez Kayani steps down, little has changed in the American-Pakistani relationship despite years of diplomatic effort.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — When he leaves his post on Friday, Gen. Ashfaq Parvez Kayani, the inscrutable Pakistani Army chief and former spymaster, will end a nearly decade-long chapter as the focus of American fears and frustrations in Pakistan, the reluctant partner in a contentious and often ill-tempered strategic dance.

articles.headline: Exhausted Shoppers Head Home, Replaced by the Next Wave
articles.snippet: As overnight shoppers packed it in, more flooded stores at dawn in search of Black Friday deals.
articles.abstract: As overnight shoppers packed it in, more flooded stores at dawn in search of Black Friday deals.
articles.lead_paragraph: With nine family members — adults, teenagers and a toddler in tow — Ludivina Zuniga stretched her shopping spree over two days and never left the Harlem Irving Plaza mall in a Chicago suburb.
